text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC when he ran for president to
preserve racial segregation in the 1960s
George Wallace used to complain there's
not a dimes worth of difference between
the Democratic and Republican parties
but because the two parties have sorted
out ideologically in the years since
then that's not really true anymore
that's why the turn to the general
election that occurs this week is such a
significant shift in the 2008 race so
far we've had internal self contained
conversations within each party with
most candidates agreeing with each other
John McCain and fellow Republicans
supported the Iraq war supported
President Bush's tax cuts were skeptical
of government-run health care Barack
Obama Hillary Clinton and other
Democrats United around the opposite
view but now that Barack Obama and John
McCain have emerged as the candidates
for the fall we have a clear clash
between Republican conservatism and
Democratic liberalism it promises to be
a close race the tide of recent American
history favors John McCain Republicans
have won nine of the last fourteen
presidential elections but right now a
political wave has crested in opposition
to george w bush's presidency due in
part to an unpopular iraq war in a
weakening economy you can see the
results in the most recent NBC Wall
Street Journal poll forty-six percent of
Americans identified themselves as
Democrats just thirty three percent as
Republicans that's a big shift from the
2004 election day when Republicans and
Democrats turned out in equal
proportions Barack Obama's task over the
next twenty two weeks is to hold that
partisan high ground John McCain by
contrast has got to use policy
differences to try to maximize his
ideological edge there are after all
more conservatives than liberals in the
United States the poll show right now
that Barack Obama begins that general
election sprint with a slight advantage
but the advantages with in the polls
margin of error
